Benefits has the meaning given in the 1987 Act and the 1998 Act and includes payments made to Workers for:
(a) compensation payable on death;
(b) weekly compensation for income and support;
(c) medical, hospital rehabilitation, legal and related expenses; and
(d) non-economic loss and property damage.
For avoidance of doubt, Benefits includes amounts payable to Third Party Service Providers by the Nominal Insurer.

Description:
A business (including an individual) that employs or hires workers on a full-time, part-time or casual basis, under an oral or written contract of service or apprenticeship or traineeship.
Categories of employers include:
•Relationship managed employers – The Organization personally manages the relationship with the employer to manage their policy
•Experience rated employers – medium and large employers are "experience-rated" with an average performance premium (total wages x your industry rate) greater than $30,000
•Mainstream employers – all other employers
Employers are categorised according to a matrix:
•By size
•By industry type
•By intermediary (broker)

Description:
Waivers can only be applied to late payment fees.

A waiver can be applied to an amount that was correctly charged but the Scheme Agent or WorkCover subsequently decides to relinquish their claim to the charge.

Examples are where a late payment fee has been correctly imposed but the employer has been able to demonstrate, given their good past payment performance that the late payment fee should not be payable by them. Waivers can also arise where WorkCover due to natural disasters (e.g. drought) has directed that certain types of employers in a particular geographic location are not to be charged a late payment fee for a specified period.
Usage Context:

Waivers can also arise where WorkCover due to natural disasters (e.g. drought) has directed that certain types of employers in a particular geographic location are not to be charged a late payment fee for a specified period.
